text: <@U051MHBQU>: sounds reasonable. Probably doesn’t even need to be an Ember object. Just a plain old javascript object often does the trick.
you might want to create a service to be in charge of that piece of data
but you may also find you don’t need the extra complexity yet

<@U03V8V08M>: I’ll give it a go with a plain old javascript object first then and see if the logic starts to bloat. In the meantime it turns out <http://forecast.io|forecast.io> doesn’t like their API being used in a pure javascript app so I have to build an API proxy for it.
Back to Rails for now, maybe rebuild the API proxy in Phoenix further down the line
APIs, why do they have to be so inconvenient?

this is all because google have deprecated geolocation over HTTP, so I have to move to HTTPS but OpenWeather is only over HTTP and then I get the mix of secure and insecure origins error so I have to then get a HTTPS API which is <http://Forecast.IO|Forecast.IO> which I decided to do in Ember because Ember and it makes local SSL easy
